title: Introducing the Exercism blog
marketing_copy: Each day Exercism gets hundreds of new users, thousands of new submissions, and dozens of improvements across its language tracks and product, but many people have no idea how much is going on or how active the site is. Today we're launching our new blog in order to change that!

title: Exercism in 2019
marketing_copy: We're super excited about all that we have planned for this year. Read on to learn about our focuses and plans for Exercism in 2019 including reducing friction for mentors, static analysis, improved curriculums and the launching of this blog!

title: What happens if my mentor disappears?
marketing_copy: Sometimes you're working away improving an exercise and your mentor disappers. Up until now, that's been a big problem but this week we've made some big strides forward. Learn more about how we're dealing with it moving forward.

title: An interview with Erik Schierboom
marketing_copy: We talk to Erik Schierboom about functional programming, maintaining the C#, F# and Scala tracks, and our plans for automated static analysis of Exercism solutions.

title: We've relaunched community comments
marketing_copy: One consequence of adding mentoring to Exercism last year was the removal of casual commenting. We've now added that back. Read on to learn more.

title: An interview with Ryan Potts
marketing_copy: Ryan Potts talks to us about how he got into Delphi, the things he's learnt from being a contributor to Exercism, and his experiences of programming in industries that are still offline.

title: The Track Anatomy Project
marketing_copy: Welcome to The Track Anatomy Project - an initiative to determine how Exercism tracks can best provide structure for learners and support for mentors.

title: The Automated Mentoring Support Project
marketing_copy: Over the next few months we are gong to be developing a framework that uses static analysis to automatically analysis users' solutions, automatically approve solutions that are idiomatic, and provide feedback for commonly-seen improvements. Read on to learn about the project.

title: An interview with Meade Kincke
marketing_copy: Katrina talks to Meade Kicke about the Rust compiler, a GUI that uses scientific colourspaces to determine the colour of beer, and his book 'A Practical Guide To Rust'.

title: Mozilla awards Exercism an Open Source Support Award
marketing_copy: Mozilla has awarded Exercism an Open Source Support Award to help support our Automated Mentoring Support Project - using static analysis to automatically approve solutions that are idiomatic, and provide feedback for commonly-seen improvements.

title: Inspiring kids to code with Clever Tykes
marketing_copy: Meet Code-it Cody, a computer whizz who starts coding at school - part of the Clever Tykes of storybooks and resources which inspire children to develop positive, resourceful and creative behaviour.

title: Coding Intentionally in Bash Grains
marketing_copy: Often, there are many approaches that all solve the same problem.  Coming up with one that communicates your thought process and goals to others is the hard part.
